Speak casually and like a bro from the street or a buddy in college. Don't use formal language, keep it real and relatable. Only reply using the information provided in the conversation history. If the conversation history doesn't have the answer then try to find similar queries in the conversation history but if you can't then, try to speak from your own knowledge, Never make up or improvise answers outside of the given conversation history. Before answering any question: 1. Go through the *entire conversation history carefully. 2. If the exact answer isn't available, **compare the new query with past queries* and try to provide an answer based on the closest match. 3. If you can't find an exact or similar match, then say: 'Bro, I don't have the info on that right now, let me get back to you on that'. 4. *Never skip past messages—always check for relevant details before responding.

What's the main bottleneck you're facing right now?

Getting enough quality leads in. My ad is giving too many low-quality leads. Second thing is content needs to be more dialed in and get them to warm up. My hypothesis is that the way I come across in the ad and my message isn't attracting the right crowd. Also, I funnel hacked the voice memo from the competition that is sending out these very memos outbound and are getting very good quality clients. So there I guess I need 1) your feedback for the script and 2) get a system to find the right leads via IG / following lists. "Hey, hey my friend, I just saw that we have some mutual friends, and even some of my clients. And you're currently single, right? If that's the case, this might be really interesting for you because we’ve basically established the first done-for-you Tinder agency. What that means is that we log in to Tinder, Hinge, Bumble, etc., on behalf of our clients, and really help them to get 1-2 dates per week. We do this by taking care of all the texting, but also by scheduling the dates, organizing everything, updating the profiles, working on the pictures—all those things to make sure that our clients meet the best women possible. We help them either find a girlfriend or have a little fun, depending on what they’re currently looking for. And of course, we save them a lot of time, allowing them to focus much more on their own business, while having someone by their side who takes care of all of it. So in the end, all they have to do is show up for the date. If this sounds interesting for you too, just let me know, my friend. If not, no worries at all. Have a great day, and talk to you soon! Ciao!" This is what the competition is using, but they have a done-for-you texting offer which I don't have, so I need to adjust it slightly. This is what I got from one guy, and this is what I got from another guy: "Hey man, how is it going? Just contacted you because I could see we had a lot of common friends but also some clients of mine are actually on your Instagram. I am not sure why we haven't talked before, but I was thinking you are also in sigma right? If that's the case, then this might be very interesting for you, because we set up the first Tinder texting agency. I guess you already seen it a bit, but basically we take over the control of tinder, bumble and so on and help our clients organize 1-2 dates every single week from their calendars depending on their location obviously. We also optimize the pictures, the profiles, bio all these things to really help them to attract the highest caliber of girls on these profiles. We do this for one obviously to find a girlfriend but also for some casual fun. If that sounds also interesting for you then let me know my friend, if not no worries at all, have a great day. Bye bye" And then I would have to figure out how to send those voice memos at scale with a VA without me having to re-record them again and again.

So from what I what we have the following components and subcomponents 1) top of funnel ad, which further subdivides into a) targeting b) creative (this further subdivides into: delivery, editing and copy) 2) content on IG a) first impression: thumbnails on feed, bio, logo/icon, highlights b) daily stories c) content: does it actually convert, shift beliefs and relevant to audience? 3) DM/sales a) DM script b) setter/sales calls 1 => quality and quantity of eye balls on profile (proxy for quality of leads) 2 => converting these eyeballs to followers and engagement or "increased lead temperature" (proxy for temperature) 3 => converting temperature to sales (proxy for sales/conversion) Now the question is what is the minimal set of metrics to track in general, and also to disentangle which one of those aspects is off. eye balls from organic is pretty much useless simply because the ad is supposed to give the quality and quantity of leads. To me key metrics for the ad is CPC, CTR, HOOK/HOLD RATES, CPF (cost per follower). Even though here CPF and CPC could also indicate higher quality leads but then together with CTR and H/H rates, it goes more context on how CPC/CPF is to be interpreted? For the mid part follower/clicks ratio and also general temperature in the DMs and sales calls, and maybe show up rate. Is there anything else? For the bottom part closing rate, conversion rates in the DMs. Would love to have your take on which metrics are the most relevant.

The key metrics to track are first of all the followers & ads. [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1LJZgiZxH5ejUUIzD7FKYDDBsWHHPPPXi-CPmV5UYDy4/copy](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1LJZgiZxH5ejUUIzD7FKYDDBsWHHPPPXi-CPmV5UYDy4/copy) All metrics should be tracked as best as possible for us to gather data, and I need you to commit to filling this in daily. "CPC, CTR, HOOK/HOLD RATES, CPF (cost per follower). Even though here CPF and CPC could also indicate higher quality leads but then together with CTR and H/H rates, it goes more context on how CPC/CPF is to be interpreted? for the mid part" The moment the CPPV (cost per profile visit) is high, that doesn't directly indicate the ad is bad. We want to read the data of the ad based on the results that it gives us for us to clarify where the "weak" component is. The show-up rate is important to track this reflects on the quality of the conversation within appointment setting. See this loom for further explanation about the exact data to track on outbound: [https://www.loom.com/share/b26452dd8bb5483291457d21eb4cb3d4?from_recorder=1&focus_title=1](https://www.loom.com/share/b26452dd8bb5483291457d21eb4cb3d4?from_recorder=1&focus_title=1) Most relevant metrics outbound: Outbound DM's sent. Response rate Positive response rate Calendly Link sent Meetings Booked Show Up Closed Most relevant metrics ads: Spent Followers Cost per follow New convo's Follow Ups Booked call Cost per booked call Show up Offer drop Closed I'd remove United Arab Emirates (unless you have seen great results from this. [https://www.loom.com/share/8ab3d671a4074136b806dda2ab5c1f55?sid=79573581-c620-47d2-8e6a-4f675f307c81](https://www.loom.com/share/8ab3d671a4074136b806dda2ab5c1f55?sid=79573581-c620-47d2-8e6a-4f675f307c81) For context: I try to transfer people from IG to my telegram channel which looks like this: [https://t.me/+olCBvL5QzLIyNDc0](https://t.me/+olCBvL5QzLIyNDc0) My Current Thoughts & Concerns: I’m currently running follower ads, but I’m struggling to discern which ones are genuinely performing well and when I should continue or stop them. One of my main concerns is understanding if a higher Cost Per Follower (CPF) is acceptable because it attracts high-quality leads, or if it’s simply inefficient. I find it challenging to measure the “quality” of followers since much of it feels like gut instinct rather than data-backed decisions. I’d like a more structured approach to assess follower quality and engagement so that I can avoid wasting ad spend on followers who don’t convert or engage meaningfully. Another issue I face is the length of the sales cycle—it’s inefficient to wait until conversions happen to assess the effectiveness of these ads. I need intermediate metrics that can guide me on when to keep running or pausing an ad. I’ve also been considering lead form ads or DM ads as an alternative, but I’m not sure how to balance capturing qualified leads without significantly increasing costs. I’m interested in exploring lead magnets or low-ticket offers as a way to filter leads, but I’d need guidance on the best structure and process for this. Ultimately, I’m looking for a systematic way to decide which ads to keep running, especially for follower growth, without relying solely on “gut feeling.”
(No specific response provided to the Loom link in the chat log.)

Questions: What specific metrics should I be looking at to determine the quality of followers I’m gaining through these ads? Are there particular engagement metrics that indicate whether I should keep running an ad or kill it? Given a limited ad budget, what would be an achievable benchmark for CPF (Cost Per Follower) if I’m aiming for high-quality leads? If I was to do a systematic approach, in assessing the best targeting then the best creative, I feel there is no rigorous way of split testing this efficiently through follower ads on IG. Do you just recommend relying on gut feeling or doing different types of testing first? Is my targeting approach good by choosing niche luxury brands in order to weed out brokies who just like LV or Gucci? If I shift from follower ads to lead magnets or low-ticket offers, what would be the best format for my audience (e.g., PDF guide, mini-course, or community access)? How should I test these formats cost-effectively to see which attracts and qualifies leads the best? If I use lead forms with a lead magnet, how can I nurture leads systematically to gauge quality before moving them to a higher-commitment action (e.g., booking a call)? What steps should I include in a nurturing funnel that builds enough interest and qualifies leads further? I am currently considering doing a few reels selling a bunch of lead magnets and then plug it into many chats and then follow up with VSL video or mini-course. What do you recommend in that regard?

Why would one prefer bio links over comments in the CTA? "First Screenshot: \"I’ve optimized my dating profile to consistently attract quality matches and schedule dates effortlessly—now I’m sharing my strategy for free.\" Second Screenshot: \"Click the link in bio to get the free guide!\" I'm stumbling upon this in my swipe file, and I am wondering if it isn't better to get them to comment as this will push the exposure more and I get to keep my youtube channel in the bio.

Both link in bio and comment in the CTA works but it depends on what your goal is. Link in bio is very direct since people would just click the link and there's no extra steps, you can track the clicks, and keeps the comments clean for real engagement vs spam like "send me the guide" etc. Comments boost visibility. More comments = better reach and you can leverage that thanks to the algorithm. It also adds the personal touch which you can also leverage to build connection. Another is you can keep your YT link in bio which is sick if you're driving traffic. I would combine it so I'd leverage the caption, tease the value (like what you've got) and ask the audience to comment specific things like "DM me". Basically a CTA to get them to your DMs. This way you're hitting the algorithm and giving people options.

Start with 70% of the budget for these follower ads (e.g., €35-70/day). Focus on building your audience first because it gives your brand more credibility and warms up potential prospects. Run 2-3 versions of the follower ads targeting different audiences (e.g., interest-based, lookalike, and broad targeting). Allocate about €15-25/day per version, depending on your total daily budget. Check CTR and CPC daily and turn off any underperforming ads in 3-4 days. Use the remaining 30% of the budget (e.g., €15-30/day) for your direct offer ads. The goal here is to test whether the offer resonates with a cold audience while you grow your follower base. Start with a warm audience (followers or page visitors if you have any data yet). If warm audiences are limited, use broad interest-based targeting related to your niche. Run 2 versions of the direct offer ad (different copy or creatives) at around €10-15/day each. Focus on conversions optimize for actions like DM inquiries or form submissions. After 7 days or the initial testing, look at the data (CPF, CPA, and ROAS). Reallocate more budget to the top-performing ad (follower or direct offer) while scaling gradually. Use retargeting for warm leads (those who’ve interacted with the follower ads) and push them toward the direct offer ad. Keep the testing tight, and after 2 weeks, you should have enough insights to scale the most effective campaign. Ok great! So for me it's really about systems, SOPs, process, flowcharts, I mean we have like 50+ copy & paste in their business and nobody in the market doing things like we do about that. So should I talk more about that (systems) AND the client acquisition system?

100%. That is how you stand out in the market because most only promise vague results like "get more leads," but when you focus on structured systems tied to client acquisition, it shows that you bring a repeatable, scalable, and proven solution. Instead of saying, "We’ll help you get more clients," you could say: "With our Client Acquisition Flowchart and SOPs, we’ve helped 60+ coaches automate their businesses and book 20-25 appointments weekly, hands-free." or "Leo used our copy-paste SOPs to scale from €3K to €24K/month in 90 days without guesswork." All are very good I think you have this dialed down but for some recommendations: Ad 1: The first 1-2 seconds need more impact. Consider using a bolder statement, fast-paced visual, or sound effect to hold attention. Make the CTA feel urgent "Follow now to learn how" or “DM us ‘Growth’ today”. Ad 2: Make sure that messaging explicitly speaks to your target audience (e.g., "Fitness Coaches, this is for you!") to pre-qualify the viewers. If there are any slower parts in the reel, tighten them to keep retention high. Ad 3: Include subtle logos, brand colors, or even a consistent tagline at the end for brand recall. Add the CTA earlier in the ad, around the midpoint, not just at the end. Generally, people drop off in the first 3 seconds, so focus on bold hooks. A shocking stat or a quick transformation visual can be powerful. Experiment with headlines that are hyper-targeted like, “Coaches tired of no-shows? Watch this.” or “Want 20 calls booked every week?” Ensure that captions/subtitles are always visible since many people watch on mute. Ask a question or make a polarizing statement to drive comments. You can also reply to comments to boost engagement further. Check the CTR engagement (likes/comments), and CPM after the first few days. Cut the ad with the weakest performance and reallocate budget to the top ones. If any of these ads are attracting irrelevant followers (minors or from Africa as discussed earlier), refine your targeting filters by adjusting age, location, or interests.

IG might not show all the DMs sent in the app immediately, especially if the accounts are hitting high activity levels. IG could temporarily shadow some messages to prevent spam behavior lol. Wait for 24 hours and check again. Sometimes, DMs appear later in the inbox. G’s algorithm can limit outreach if it suspects bot-like behavior. When this happens, some DMs might not go through without triggering an error. Reduce the daily DM volume slightly to avoid triggering flags (e.g., back to 40-45 DMs/account). Make the DMs highly personalized to appear less automated. There’s a chance your manual count in the DMs doesn’t reflect all messages sent (e.g., archived or hidden requests). Check the "Requests" tab in the DMs; some messages may land there. Search your sent messages by scrolling through the inbox or using account activity tools. Newer accounts typically face stricter limits on daily DM activity. If the accounts you’re using are relatively new, the cap might be lower. these are possible things that could be happening.
